column1: 0: THERE was once upon a time a poor widow who had an only son named Jack, and a cow named Milky-white.
1: And all they had to live on was the milk the cow gave every morning, which they carried to the market and sold.

15: "As you are so sharp," says he, "I don't mind doing a swop with you—your cow for these beans."

22: "Back already, Jack?" said his mother; "I see you haven't got Milky-white, so you've sold her, How much did you get for her?"

45: And when he got there he found a long broad road going as straight as a dart.

51: You'd better be moving on or he'll soon be coming."
53: I've had nothing to eat since yesterday morning, really and truly, mum," says Jack, "I may as well be broiled as die of hunger."
55: So she took Jack into the kitchen, and gave him a junk of bread and cheese and a jug of milk.
56: But Jack hadn't half finished these when thump!
63: And she bundled Jack into the oven just as the ogre came in.
64: He was a big one, to be sure.

102: But that was all Jack heard, for he rushed off to the beanstalk and climbed down like a house on fire.
103: And when he got home he showed his mother the wonderful hen, and said "Lay" to it; and it laid a golden egg every time he said "Lay."

126: But the harp called out quite loud: "Master! Master!"
